reference.title: Backing up and restoring applications
reference.shortdesc: In some situations, you might want to back up configuration information and data from an application and then later restore that instance. You might back up on a regular schedule to provide a historical archive; or infrequently, such as when you want to move data from one instance to another or perhaps duplicate an instance for testing or failover purposes.

section.p: The backup process saves the state of all services and data to a .tgz file that you can restore on that cluster or duplicate on a similar cluster. The state of the system at the time of the backup is stored; however, specific snapshots are not backed up. As a best practice, take periodic backups.There may be occasions when a full backup is not necessary, for example, a checkpoint prior to installing software. In these cases, you can perform a snapshot of the system. In the event that you need to revert back to a snapshot, you can use the rollback feature (before which you will need to stop services that are used in the particular snapshot image). For more information, see . You must perform your backups on the instance using the documented procedures below. Do not use the backup and restore functionality provided by your vSphere environment as a substitute to these procedures.
